The treatise states:
In order to distinguish and uphold the true meaning in the arguments, this treatise is composed.
Verse:
The many statements such as the thesis are able to establish, in this only following one's own intention;
What is said to be established is called the thesis, not the meaning that contradicts it can eliminate it.
The treatise states:
The meaning of the faults in establishing and the true meaning of the seal are now composed in this treatise.
The many statements such as the thesis are able to establish like this and so forth, this statement is to show the means, the interpreted meaning, and the purpose.
As for the means, it is for the sake of the means such as benefiting all sentient beings and so forth.
As for the interpreted meaning, it refers to the interpreted meaning, namely the thesis and so forth.
As for the matter of the purpose, it is for the sake of sealing the true meaning.

If it is to show the result of the reason, placing this statement at the beginning of the treatise, because this meaning has already been shown elsewhere, like direct perception, what is meant by elsewhere?
After understanding the treatise, because of this, it should not be said at the beginning.
If so, because it is not a part of the treatise, like other statements.
Because this meaning has already been shown elsewhere, this reason is not established.

One who understands the treatise later and only then understands the meaning, the prior awareness of the reason, etc., if not understood at the beginning, does not proceed. Because of this understanding, one then accords with the later time.
Because it is not a part of the treatise, this is also not established.
If one has this intention, since it is neither a sÅ«tra nor its explanation, it must not be a branch. Who explains this sÅ«tra?
Who is the sÅ«tra explained by?

Therefore, one should know that like the words of Devadatta, which are not its branches, the reason, etc., of the treatises are also established as parts. Because this reason exists, it is far removed from non-establishment.
Others again object:
Do not compose this treatise, because it has no basis, etc., like the words of a madman.
To show that this reason is not established.
The reply is:
What is meant by valid proof and refutation, etc.
If it is said that this is so, do not compose this treatise, because it explains the meaning that has already been shown, like the second method.
Aká¹£apÄda has already explained the characteristics of the thesis, etc., and this reason shows that it is not established.
Isn't it that valid proof, etc. have the meaning of authenticating reality?
However, this treatise, etc. do not authenticate the meaning of reality, and therefore it is a fault of non-establishment.
Up to this point, the master of the treatise has already explained the thesis.
From here on, the main text will be explained in order.

The many statements such as the thesis are able to establish means that by means of the many statements explaining the thesis, reason, and example, the meaning that others have not yet understood is revealed. These many statements are called able to establish in the treatise and other texts.

Moreover, by saying in one word to refer to the proponent, it is to show that they collectively form one type of proponent. From this, one should know that if any part is missing, it is a fallacy of the proponent.
As for the phrase in this, it has the meaning of initiating a discussion, or the meaning of selecting and upholding. It is called in this because it is within the thesis and so forth.
As for the word only, it has the meaning of distinguishing and differentiating.
According to one's own intention shows not caring about the thesis of the opponent, but establishing according to one's own intention.
What is desired refers to what is to be established, that is, not what is desired to be the nature of the means of establishing.
If it were otherwise, then what is to be established, similar to a reason, and similar to an example, should also be called a thesis.
In order to show that it is free from the fallacies of establishing a thesis, it says the meaning that is contrary to it cannot be refuted.
If the meaning that is contrary to it is refuted by the sound of words, like establishing all words are false;
or if it contradicts the meaning of the thesis that was previously established, like the son of a fox establishing sound is permanent;

Moreover, if in the middle [of the proof statement] there is a reason that is not commonly accepted, then the statement of what is commonly accepted contradicts the meaning, just as in saying The rabbit does not have the moon because it does not have the moon.

Moreover, regarding the property-possessor, if what is established contradicts the meaning of what is commonly accepted by direct perception and inference, it is refuted, just as in establishing Sound is not audible or A pot is permanent and so on.
Those who say that contradicting the thesis and reason is called contradicting the thesis are not at fault in the thesis;

because in this case, establishing Sound is permanent, because all are impermanent is a bad establishment of a dissimilar example by means of a combined example, because it shows that not all [are impermanent].
This reason does not exist, because sound is included in all.
Or because it is a part of the meaning to be established, this meaning is not established, and is called a fault of the reason.
The example also has a fault, because by a dissimilar example, the absence of the thesis is first shown, and then the absence of the reason is stated.
It should be stated like this:
Impermanent and all is called not not all.
However, this is an inverted statement that all are impermanent, and therefore the analogy here also has a fault.
Thus, the thesis and pseudo-thesis have been explained.
The reason and pseudo-reason are mostly the property of the thesis. The characteristics of their distinctions will now be revealed.
Verse:
The property of the thesis in the similar instance is said to be existent, non-existent, and both;
In the dissimilar instance, there are three each: existent, non-existent, and both.
Commentary:
Isn't it that the thesis is generally established by pleasure and spoken of together?
How is it that in this context the thesis only takes the property of the subject?
This is not a mistake.
Because the general sound also applies to the individual, like saying burning clothes;
Or there is a thesis sound that only expresses the property.
Here, the property of the thesis only takes what is definitely agreed upon by the proponent and the opponent.
In the similar class, existence, non-existence, etc. are also like this.
Why is this?
Now, this only relies on the cause of proof and understanding, and only by the power of wisdom one understands the meaning of what is said, not like a productive cause that gives rise to function.
If that is so, since one takes wisdom as the cause of understanding, then speech loses the meaning of being able to establish.
This is also not so, because it causes them to remember what was originally well-established. Therefore, in this case, only taking what is definitely accepted by both parties is well-said.
Thus, if there is something that is not accepted by both parties, it definitely is not a property of the thesis, like establishing sound is impermanent because it is seen by the eye.
Moreover, if the opponent does not accept it, like in the case of the VaibhÄá¹£ika, because of being produced.
Moreover, if there is doubt, like when giving rise to doubt based on smoke, etc., establishing fire exists in the combination of the primary elements, because smoke is present.
Or, in this case, the property to be established may not be established, as in the argument the self is all-pervading, because it produces pleasure, etc., everywhere.
All such statements of this kind are not valid proofs.
The presence or absence of the reason in similar instances should also be explained accordingly, as appropriate.
In the case of a reason that contradicts the probandum or is inconclusive, only statements that are commonly accepted and certain are called valid proofs or refutations.
Ambiguous statements that are not mutually established require further proof.
When establishing a thesis, one should further use other properties as reasons to establish that property:
If one establishes the property-possessor as existent or non-existent, as in the argument the supreme is existent, because it is seen that separate things have a general category;
Or, it is established as non-existent, because it is not apprehended.
What is the meaning of this?
Here, only the proposition that there is definitely one cause for a separate entity is established, not the most excellent, so there is no such fault.
If it is established as non-existent, it is also provisionally established as the dharma of non-attainment, so there is also no fault of having an existent dharma.
If an existent dharma is established as another existent dharma, or if its dharma is established, like establishing fire with smoke, or establishing touch with fire, what is the meaning?
Here, fire and touch are not established as the proposition, but only the corresponding entity is established.
If it were not so, then establishing fire based on smoke and establishing touch based on fire would constitute a part of the proposition as the reason.
Moreover, here it is not intended to establish that fire and touch have nature, because it is commonly known that they exist.
Moreover, here the dharma and existent dharma are observed to be established, not quality and possessor of quality, so there is no fault.
A verse is restated:
There is a dharma that is not established in the existent dharma, and the dharma is not established in the existent dharma;
But only by the dharma is the dharma established, in this way the existent dharma is established.
The treatise says:

If there is an establishment that sound is not permanent, because the effect and so forth should be permanent, because the permanent should be apprehensible, how is this called the property of the thesis?

This is said to be the fault of the reason, because by the door of the thesis there is something to be established, and the word should is used, because it was previously established that the permanent is without form and obstruction, and later only the thesis is established, refuting the fault of the reason.
If it is established in this way that sound is impermanent, because the produced is not permanent, because the permanent is not the produced, what is this again?
This is the expedient of the example.

The similar property and the dissimilar property, in their respective order, proclaim the reason, because the thesis is definitely concomitant, and because where there is no thesis there is definitely no reason.

Because in this case, the nature of being a product is shown by combination. In this way, this sound is definitely a product, not non-product. This nature of being a product is definitely a property of the thesis.
Repeating the verse, it says:
Stating the reason, it follows the thesis;
Without the thesis, the reason does not exist.
Relying on the fifth, the example, one knows the reason by combination.
The treatise says:

By this, the method of refutation is already explained, because the nature of being a product is seen in the impermanent, and because it is not seen in the permanent. In this way, it is established that sound is not permanent, because it should not be a product.
Therefore, the method of affirmation and refutation is not a separate explanation of the reason.
As for refuting the SÄá¹ƒkhya, I have already extensively argued, so one should stop the extensive discussion of the subsidiary argument.
Thus, there are three kinds of distinctions in the property of the thesis, namely:
Presence in the similar instance, absence in the dissimilar instance, and both.
First, remove the word and.
Here, if a class is proximate and equal to what is being established, it is called a similar class, because all meanings are called classes.
If what is being established does not exist, it is said to establish a dissimilar class, not in contradiction with or different from the similar class.
If it were in contradiction, it should only be a distinction;
if it were different, there should be no reason.
By this principle, because of being produced can establish impermanence and non-self and so on, because there is no contradiction.
If a dharma can establish a contradiction to what is being established, it is a contradictory fault, and is called a pseudo-reason.
Like a dharma without contradiction, a contradiction is also like this:
Because the dharma to be established does not exist, it definitely does not exist.
It is not like a pot, where the reason establishes doubt, because there is no intermediate state between them.
Because being produced is seen to exist apart from a pot, in clothes and so on, but does not exist apart from impermanence in non-self and so on, because this reason exists.
How does a separate dharma operate in a separate place?
Because they are similar, we do not speak of a different name. Saying it is just this is therefore without error.
If we do not speak of a difference, how can this reason be called the property of the thesis?
Here we only speak of what is definitely the property of the thesis, not wishing to say it is only the property of the thesis.
If that is so, then the similar instance should also be called the thesis?
No, because it is said to be what is to be established in a different place.

The reason must be definitely different in order to constitute inference, so it is not similar.ğŸ”½Moreover, each of these has three kinds. Among all the similar instances, in the dissimilar instances, there is either existence, non-existence, or both existence and non-existence.
In the similar instances, there is non-existence and both existence and non-existence. Each has these three kinds of distinctions.
If the thesis of impermanence has no dissimilar instances at all, and one does not argue that space and so forth exist, how can one say that it does not exist there?
If it does not exist there, it does not operate there. There is no doubt at all, so there is no error in this.

Thus, these nine types of properties of the probandum are formed. Their characteristics are briefly explained in order. For example, it is established that sound is permanent, because it is an object of cognition;
Or it is established that it is impermanent, because it is a product;ğŸ”½Or it is established that it is produced by the exertion of effort, because it is impermanent;
Or it is established that it is permanent, because it is a product;
Or it is established that it is permanent, because it is audible;ğŸ”½Or it is established that it is permanent, because it is produced by the exertion of effort;
Or it is not produced by the exertion of effort, because it is impermanent;ğŸ”½Or it is established that it is impermanent, because it is produced by the exertion of effort;
Or it is established that it is permanent, because it is intangible.
These nine types are summarized in two verses:
The verse says:
Permanence, impermanence, exertion, constancy, enduring, solidity,
Not diligent, changing, and unchanging, due to the nine such as the object of measurement.
The object of measurement, action, impermanence, the nature of action, hearing, courageous effort,
Impermanence, courage, and non-contact, relying on the nature of permanence and the other nine.
The treatise says:
This kind of distinction is called reason, contradictory, and indefinite, therefore the original verse says:
In the same, there is both, in the different, there is none, this is the reason.
The opposite is called contradictory, the rest are all indefinite.
Among these, there are only two kinds called reasons, namely, in the similar class, universally present, and in the different class, completely absent;
And in the similar class, either present or absent, and in the different class, completely absent.
In the first and last three, each takes one from the middle.
There are also only two kinds called contradictory, because they can overturn, namely, in the different class, present and two kinds;
In the similar class, completely absent.
The second three take the first and last two.
The remaining five kinds, cause and contradiction, are all uncertain, which is the meaning of the cause of doubt.

Moreover, in the characteristics of all causes, etc., the same number and type of what is said are all said. Do not say that the two characteristics mutually contradict each other and gather together as a cause, etc., or in the same characteristic, they act together to form an all-encompassing cause.
Reasonably, the four kinds should be called uncertain causes, because both exist.
What is meant by what is heard?
Because of the unique.
If it is unique, the differences in the established dharma, which pervade and include everything, are all the causes of doubt.
Only because of the nature of existence and what is included in it, one is completely separated.
All that exists is common, without a distinguishing cause.
This is only in that, both are not contradictory, which is the nature of the cause of doubt.
If in the middle, both parts exist, it is also a definite cause, because it distinguishes the rest. This is called difference.
If one argues that sound has the nature of existence and is permanent, this should be a reason.
If at that time there is no indication that the nature of being produced is a reason for impermanence, this meaning may be possible;
But since both are mutually contradictory and not allowed, it is a reason of doubt.
Moreover, in this case, the power of direct perception and scripture is superior, therefore one should rely on this to seek certainty.
Summarizing the above verse, it says:
If a dharma is unique, common, or definitely contradictory,
Pervasive to all of them, it is all a reason of doubt.
Wrongly proving the dharma and the dharmin, the nature or the distinction,
This becomes a contradictory reason if there is no harm to the object of refutation.
Observing the dharmas of the thesis, if the desired contradiction is harmed,
It becomes hesitant and inverted, different from this is a reason without similarity.
The treatise says:ğŸ”½Thus, reasons and pseudo-reasons have been discussed.
I will now explain analogies and pseudo-analogies.
The verse says:
It is said that the reason follows the thesis.
Without the thesis, the reason does not exist.
These two are called analogies, and the rest are similar to this.
The treatise says:
There are two kinds of analogies:
Similar dharmas and dissimilar dharmas.
Similar dharmas means establishing that sound is impermanent because it is produced by the exertion of effort.
Because all that is produced by the exertion of effort is seen to be impermanent, just like a pot, etc.
Dissimilar dharmas means that all that is permanent is not seen to be produced by the exertion of effort, like space, etc.
The former is a prohibitive statement, while the latter only stops confusion, because of the meaning of inference by combination and separation.
Therefore, although it is not established as a real existent like space, etc., it can show that where there is no thesis, there is no meaning of reason.

Moreover, what is the reason for saying in the first place that the reason follows the thesis, and in the second place that without the thesis, the reason does not exist, but not saying that without the reason, the thesis does not exist?
By explaining in this way, it can show that the reason definitely exists in the similar class and is completely absent in the dissimilar class, and is not an inverted explanation.
Moreover, it is said in verse:
One should use non-production to prove its permanence, or use impermanence to establish what is produced;
If so, it would be established as not what is being spoken of, not universal, not the combination or separation of pleasure, etc.
The treatise says:
Thus, the two methods of combination and separation in accordance with and in opposition to the two analogies have been explained.
The meaning of similar analogies is similar to this.
What is meant by this?
It refers to the place where, although there is combination and separation of the established, the means of establishing, and the dissimilar class, they are explained in an inverted manner.

Or, in this place, combination and separation are not made, and only the presence of the established and the means of establishing together, and the absence of the dissimilar class together, are shown.
In this way, there are two methods for these two dharmas, either one is not established or not eliminated, or both are not established or not eliminated.
For example, establishing sound is permanent, because it is intangible.

The same-type example is stated as All that is not contacted is seen to be permanent, like karma, like atoms, like a pot, etc.ğŸ”½The different-type example is stated as All that is seen to be impermanent is contacted, like atoms, like karma, like space, etc.
Based on this, it has already been explained that in the same-type example, the property of the position is not established, referring to the permanent space, etc. that the opponent does not accept.
Is it necessary to have both metaphorical statements in order for it to be a valid proof?
Or is it like its reason, where only one is stated?

If it is based on the correct principle, both should be stated, because this fully shows that what is to be established is not separate from its reason. By fully showing that the same type definitely has it and the different type does not have it everywhere, it can correctly counteract contradiction and uncertainty.
If one part of this is already established, then stating only one part is also a valid proof.
If it is like its sound, where both meanings are accepted as the same, then both do not need to be stated.
Or, by implication, one can show both.
Moreover, in inference, one only sees this principle:

If in the place being inferred, this characteristic is ascertained, then in other similar cases, one recollects that it definitely exists. In the absence of that, one recollects that it is completely absent everywhere. Therefore, from this, one gives rise to a definite understanding.
Thus, the original verse says:
Just as one has oneself attained certainty, one hopes that others will also give rise to certainty.
The property of the thesis, the corresponding [reason], and the probandum are stated, while the rest are to be avoided.
The treatise says:
In order to manifest the nature of the property of the thesis in the place being inferred, the reason is stated;
In order to manifest the inseparable nature of this [reason], the example is stated;
In order to manifest the place being inferred, the thesis is stated.
Within the place being inferred, apart from this, there are no other branches. Therefore, other investigations, etc., as well as combination and conclusion, are refuted.
If that is so, then the statement of the example should not be a separate part, because it manifests the meaning of the reason.

Although this is indeed the case, the statement of the reason is only for the sake of clarifying the nature of the property of the thesis, not for the sake of clarifying the presence or absence of the property in similar and dissimilar instances. Therefore, the statements of the similar and dissimilar examples must be made separately.
If the meaning expressed solely by the statement of the reason is called the reason, what fault is there in this?
What benefit is there in this?
The separate statement of the example is called the benefit.
It should be like the expedient taught in the world, which is not at all in accord with the meaning of the reason.
If so, what fault is there?

This statement should only be a class of the established meaning, without the ability [to prove], not the meaning of the proof, because it only speaks of the nature of being produced. The similar class is the same [as the reason];
it does not speak of the established and the to-be-established.

Moreover, the reason and example are different. This has the established same class and different class, but in the end it cannot manifest the inseparability of the reason and the established [probandum]. Therefore, there is only a class of the established meaning, but it lacks the ability [to prove].
Why is there no ability?
Because in the similar example, the property of the thesis and the meaning of the thesis do not necessarily correspond.
Moreover, this is established by other analogies, so it would be endless.

Moreover, there are not necessarily various categories, and in the dissimilar class, the absence of the property is not manifested. There is something to be distinguished that can serve as an analogy.
Therefore, a verse is spoken:
If the reason is only what is established, or the characteristics of distinctions correspond,
The analogy should be endless, and the dissimilar class should be refuted.
The treatise says:

In the world, only the presence of the property of the thesis and the reason in the same place as the similar class is taken as the similar example of the dissimilar property. Because where the thesis is absent, the reason is not necessarily absent, it is definitely unable [to serve as a dissimilar example].
If only the property of the thesis is the nature of the reason, then the uncertain [reason] should also be able to serve as a reason.
How is it that there is this fault in the two kinds of analogies that possess what is to be established, what establishes, and the dissimilar class?

If at that time the dissimilar class established is not of a single kind, then there would be this fault, like the first, last, and middle three each being the final example. Therefore, the three characteristics are definitely only for revealing the reason.
By this principle, although all parts can serve as the reason to clarify what is established, yet only one part is said to be the reason.
Thus, the thesis, etc., and their counterparts are briefly explained. These many statements are called the means of valid proof and the counterparts of the means of valid proof.
As appropriate, in order to enlighten others, one explains these means of valid proof and their counterparts.
In order to enlighten oneself, there are only direct perception and inference. Sound, examples, etc., are included in these. Therefore, there are only two means of valid cognition.

Because by these one can understand the general and specific characteristics, apart from these two there is nothing else to be cognized. In order to understand them, one establishes the other means of valid cognition.
Therefore, the original verse says:
Direct perception excludes conceptualization, the rest are said to arise from causes.
The treatise says:

Direct perception excludes conceptualization means that if there is cognition that is far removed from all kinds of names, expressions, and hypothetical establishments regarding objects such as form, and is non-different, non-common, and turns separately due to the present, it is called direct perception.
Therefore, a verse says:
The dharma is not of a single characteristic, the faculties are not all-pervading,
Only the inner realization that is free from words is the domain of the sense faculties.
The treatise says:
The mental ground also has freedom from all conceptualization, and only turns through the practice of realization.
Moreover, the part of self-realization of greed and so forth, and the freedom from conceptualization of teachings by those who cultivate concentration, are all direct perception.
Moreover, within this there is no result of valid cognition, because this very essence arises resembling the object and resembles the function, and it is provisionally called valid cognition.
If the part of self-realization of greed and so forth is also direct perception, why is conceptualizing cognition excluded here?
It does not exclude self-realization as a kind of direct perception, because it is non-discriminating.
But in this case, the other aspects of the object are not called direct perception.

For this reason, it is said that memory, inference, desire, doubt, deluded cognition, etc., are all not direct perception with regard to the mirage, etc., because they arise from discrimination based on previous experience.

In this way, all worldly cognition with regard to conventional existence, such as cognition of pots, numbers, lifting, existence, pot-ness, etc., are all similar to direct perception, but with regard to real existence, they arise from discrimination by combining other meanings, taking on other aspects.
Direct perception has been explained. Inference will now be explained.

Cognition born from the stated reason means that cognition is the previous cognition, and the other [cognition] is born from the stated reason that establishes [the previous cognition], which is the cognition of that meaning.
This is of two kinds:
That is, the cognition that examines the inferred object arises from direct perception or from inference;

And recollecting this reason as inseparable from the thesis being established, this becomes the power of stating what has been said, because of recollecting the reason, the similar instance, and the definite presence, etc.
Because it is the cause of inference, whether near or far, it is all called inference. This is explained in terms of the instrument and the agent.
In this way, one should understand that the inference for the sake of others is also not apart from this in becoming able to establish [a thesis].
Therefore, a verse is spoken:
One thing has many dharmas, but the characteristics do not function in all;
Only by distinguishing the rest, it can indicate the definite following.
In this way, the characteristic also has many dharmas,
Only not going beyond the characterized, it can manifest, not the rest.
The treatise says:
Why is it established here separately from the previous direct perception?

The two gates should be shown. Here, the result of inference should also be called inference, and there, the cause of direct perception should also be called direct perception. Both are not prohibited.
Having already explained the valid means of proof and the semblance of the valid means of proof, we will now explain the refutation and the semblance of refutation.
Verse:
Refutation that lacks the words of deficiency, etc., is called semblance refutation.
Commentary:
Here, refutation that lacks the words of deficiency, etc. refers to the faults of the parts that lack the words of deficiency, etc. mentioned above.
Each of those words is called refutation, because each of them can reveal that the previous thesis is not well-stated.

As for the phrase semblance refutation is called the various types, the similar faults such as the similar dharmas, etc. are called semblance refutation, because they often confuse others about good inference and establish it.
They cannot reveal that the previous thesis is not well-stated, because they refute it unreasonably and establish it as the refutation.
Because they are of that type, they are called the various types.

If in the case of an unreasonable inference, one sets forth in this way, either not understanding the faults of inference, or in order to manifest the gateway to those faults, it is not called a fault.
The verse says:
Because of showing the dissimilar class,
By establishing the similar class as different from the similar class, the similar class is similar;
The other, by the dissimilar class.
Discrimination and distinction are called discrimination.
One should be established without difference.
The reason that is established is called the similar class that can be obtained.
Because the meaning of the objection is different and doubts the reason, it is called doubt.
Because of stating the meaning of the dissimilar class, the unloved is called the meaning by analogy.
The treatise says:
Among them, because of showing the dissimilar class,

by establishing the similar class as different from the similar class, the similar class is similar means that because of being established in the opposite way, it is called established as different. This is said based on the instrument and the agent.
The same dharma is similar, therefore it is called the same dharma similarity, because it is a similar fallacy in all established cases.
The word similarity is a neuter sound, because it can destroy the corresponding [fallacies] or because it follows the verse.
How can the same dharma similarity refute?
Because it is said in the accomplished [case] that it is the agent, and because it is transmitted, it is said to be so.
Later, as appropriate, it is also said in the same way.

Here, by the inversion of the same dharma simile, therefore it is called the same dharma similarity.ğŸ”½For example, in establishing sound is impermanent, because it is produced by effort and immediately, this uses space as a dissimilar example.
There is the use of space as a similar example, because it is without substance, etc., establishing sound as permanent.
In this way, in this stated reason, the pot should be the same dharma, but the dissimilar category space is said to be the same dharma, therefore it is said to be the same dharma similarity.
The rest by other dharmas means that other dharmas similar to the similar dharmas mentioned before are the rest.

The dissimilar class is shown by the other dharma example, which is established in the opposite way. Among the two kinds of examples, as previously established, the pot is the dissimilar dharma. Therefore, it is called similar to the dissimilar dharma.

The name of discrimination is discrimination means that previously it was said to show, and now it is said to discriminate differences. Therefore, one should know that the discrimination of the similar dharma is different.
It is as previously said that the pot is the similar dharma. Because there are differences such as being burnable, etc. in that similar dharma, then the pot should be impermanent;
not sound, sound should be permanent.
Because there are differences such as not being burnable, etc., this discrimination is established in the opposite way. Therefore, it is called similar to the discrimination.
What is said as should be one without difference shows that the similar dharma has already been mentioned before. Because of this, it should be the same as that.
Who is that?
Because no other means are heard again, and because they are adjacent, it should be known that this is the thesis.
Without difference means without the fault of difference.
Because the meaning can be known from this statement itself, it does not state who is together with whom to form non-difference.
Because it is not stated separately, it is all of this and all of that.

As it is said, if one sees that because of having the same dharma, then combining the other dharmas is also without difference, all the dharmas of a pot should all exist in sound, then all would mutually have the same dharma and would form a single nature.

What principle is this?
Only that which is not yet established as the property to be established before the thesis can be called a reason. Therefore, it is not the means of establishing the thesis.

In this way, there is a semblance of a reason being incomplete in the case of a reason established by verbal testimony and wisdom, and a semblance of an unestablished reason in the case of a reason established by the meaning, because it unreasonably denies the causes of phenomena.
